Message.Msg: You're right, they can't lose ground. They could ignore the Kindle Fire, the Nexus 7 could lead to too much lost sales. I think they have a plan ready in case the Nexus 7 gains traction.
It makes sense, the tablet is a conscription device which is what gaming is all about. The computer is creation device.

Apple isn't playing catch up with 7 inch, its a product they probably never want to introduce. But if they have to cut off competition from gaining traction it may be an option they will have to explore.
TSMC has slipped so far behind that they are beginning to etch their lithography on cave walls.
I am very curious to see what happens in the next six months with Apple, the three things on my watch list. ----- You should add the Apple branded TV to this list.

Message.Title: Xeon breaks Calxeda's ARM in Apache benchmark
Message.Msg: Intel has hit back at upstart server rival Calxeda, which claimed its ARM-powered servers could out do Chipzilla's machines. Calxeda pitted its ECX-1000 processors against Intel's Xeons on the Apache Bench benchmark test and boasted that its ARM chips had a sizeable advantage. Not so, says Intel, and it has the benchmark tests to prove it. ....... But, says Hill, even if you assume 11.26 watts for the ECX-1000 socket, then the Calxeda ARM server is doing around 489 Apache Bench requests per second, per watt, and the low-voltage part plus the faster networking option gives Intel's Xeon E3 v2 a 28 per cent performance per watt advantage over the ARM server. http://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/08/13/xeon_vs_calxeda_arm_apache_bench/

There'a another factor. The Intel team that promoted Centrino thought they were geniuses because they rode the growth of Wi-Fi. What really happened is that Intel launched the Centrino product line into an already growing demand for wireless connectivity which was at a tipping point already. As a result several Intel folks rode the Wi-Fi train up the Intel ladder. Not long after the Wi-Fi success Intel wanted a piece of the cellular business and the same folks that took credit for Centrino's success thought they would redefine the cellular industry with a clone of Wi-Fi they called WiMAX aimed at carrier services. Instead of building a better SoC than ARM Intel wasted more years and about $10 billion trying to establish WiMAX as the dominant 4G wireless protocol. Carriers wanted no part of it and designed LTE which won the 4G protcol war. WiMAX was an Intel authored disaster that delayed Intel pursing the right strategy which was to build a better SoC than ARM. Intel had to clean house and bring in a new team. The WiMAX group was disbanded. A lot of people were terminated, some reassigned to offices away from the HQ. And yes, Meego was another disaster, at least it didn't cost as much. Qualcomm hired damaged goods.

These were those killer numbers for TSMC that D.A.N. was boasting about? BTW, can you think of another product you can buy where they charge you for the effort of making the product even if it yields nothing? How many fisherman get paid when they don't catch fish?

Message.Title: Ryan...YES!!! END TO SOCIAL SECURITY
Message.Msg: I can't wait to see Social Security flushed down the rat hole ! Romney picked the man..the man who will eliminate social programs, social security and medicare once and for all!

I doubt it. I think you're being facetious but I will tell you one thing. Unlike Obamas social programs I've paid into Social Security my entire working life and I expect to get my money back when I retire. The key words there are "my money". I'm not asking for a handout but I do expect my effing money back.
I don't know if you'll get your money back...look what happened to Maury. But you are right about one thing...I am being facetious.
Social security is already in the rat hole , all we have to do is wait and do nothing. number of people withdrawing SOC is greater and growing than the number who put $ in.
Rice would have been a bad choice for Slick Willard. You need to remember she is lezzy. If you really needed a black running mate, Colin Powell would have been a great choice.

FDR on Social Security. NOTE.... he said "It will act as a protection to future Administrations against the necessity of going deeply into debt to furnish relief to the needy. The law will flatten out the peaks and valleys of deflation and of inflation". If only he knew what this monstrosity has become. Franklin Roosevelt's Statement on Signing the Social Security Act August 14 , 1935 Today a hope of many years' standing is in large part fulfilled. The civilization of the past hundred years, with its startling industrial changes, has tended more and more to make life insecure. Young people have come to wonder what would be their lot when they came to old age. The man with a job has wondered how long the job would last. This social security measure gives at least some protection to thirty millions of our citizens who will reap direct benefits through unemployment compensation, through old-age pensions and through increased services for the protection of children and the prevention of ill health. We can never insure one hundred percent of the population against one hundred percent of the hazards and vicissitudes of life, but we have tried to frame a law which will give some measure of protection to the average citizen and to his family against the loss of a job and against poverty-ridden old age. This law, too, represents a cornerstone in a structure which is being built but is by no means complete. It is a structure intended to lessen the force of possible future depressions. It will act as a protection to future Administrations against the necessity of going deeply into debt to furnish relief to the needy. The law will flatten out the peaks and valleys of deflation and of inflation. It is, in short, a law that will take care of human needs and at the same time provide for the United States an economic structure of vastly greater soundness. I congratulate all of you ladies and gentlemen, all of you in the Congress, in the executive departments and all of you who come from private life, and I thank you for your splendid efforts in behalf of this sound, needed and patriotic legislation. If the Senate and the House of Representatives in this long and arduous session had done nothing more than pass this Bill, the session would be regarded as historic for all time. http://docs.fdrlibrary.marist.edu/odssast.html

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: Although it was weakening, momentum stayed bullish. It is difficult to have a directional trade in this market. On one hand, the lowest VIX since summer of 2007 indicated complacency in the market. Should VIX pops, it could hurt bulls. On the other hand, never short a thinly traded market. We could see directional moves when the Europeans return from vacation later in the month. But until then, the market is likely to stay neutral in the near term. have a nice evening
